column1: Show placeholder DSs in the new app select list
column31:
h3. Why:

* Currently, we expose the placeholder data sources in a select list  separate from the “real” data sources.
* This is problematic, as:
** Users creating a new app have a hard time knowing that they can create their app without connecting their source.
** Users installing a Gallery app don’t know that if they don’t have a matching connected DS, we install the app with a placeholder. So it might look like they don't have an option to install.

*What:*

* We will add the placeholder DS to the DS select list used in both creating new apps from scratch and installing an app.
* The placeholders will be visible in this list only if the WS doesn’t have a real DS of that vendor connected to it.
* Placeholder DS will be named differently. The format will be:
** “[DS name] Placeholder (just schema, no data)”
* Remove the “Skip” button - The above changes will remove the need for such a button.

This story is a bit tricky and not yet fully defined from a product perspective.

In AI products, *starting a new chat typically creates a completely new context* - including new content, canvases, or other assets tied exclusively to that chat.

In our case, this conflicts with the current apps mechanism, where each app already holds its own set of content (canvases, queries, sources, alerts, workflows, etc.).

If we introduce a “New Chat” action as described, it will only create a new conversation layer, while keeping the underlying app content unchanged.

This would result in a “blank chat” but not a blank app, which is different from the expected behavior in most AI-driven UIs (where both chat and content reset together).

*I’m not saying this approach is necessarily wrong* - but it needs to be clearly defined and aligned from a product standpoint before we proceed with mplementation.

column1: CS agent: tell user what's going on before using tools
column31:
Currently, our CS agent calls tools, without telling the user what is going on.

This results in the “thoughts and actions” box opening without the user always understanding why.

In order to mitigate this behavior, we’d like the CS agent to provide a pre-tool message, explaining the situation.

DoD:

# Whenever the CS agent needs to use a tool to reply to a user’s requests, it will provide a preliminary message.
# The user will see the message before the T&A box opens, and the message will remain visible above (before) the T&A message.
# The message will address the following:
## That the agent understood the task at hand.
## If the agent will use tools to perform the task, it will tell the user (not in a “I’ll use the Insights tool”, but rather “I’ll start querying your AWS” - talking about what the tool will do, not the name of the tool)
## The agent will explain how what it is doing is related to the task (“I’ll start querying your AWS, to get the data you need for this question”)
## The agent will also have some rough ballpark estimation of the effort, and if it is more than casual, will add something like “this might take a couple of minutes, so bare with me”)

Currently, when a user submits a prompt in the App Builder input field, the following happen before the app us created and the user is redirected into it:

# A name and description are assigned
# A decision is made about the data sources that will be added the app

This takes quite a while. We want to mitigate this time by:

# Either creating a loader that covers the input field and “tells” the user wha’t going on
# Or creating an empty app, and assigning the above attributes when the app already exists.

column1: Connecting integrations to apps from the integration
column31:
Currently, the flow of creating and adding a new integration, datasource or connector, from an app, is somewhat broken:

* The user can begin an integration creation flow from an app, but that flow ends with the integration created in the workspace, not the app.
* They user has to return to the app, and add the newly created integration to the app.
* Adding a new integration when several apps already exists means entering each app and adding the integration from there.

The following solution aims to:

* Allow users to run a single flow of adding a new integration to an app from the app. Meaning, a single flow that creates the integration and adds it to the app.
* Allow users to easily add an integrations to all existing apps - both when creating a new integration and when managing a previously existing one.

DoD:

# At the end of the integration process (for DS or connector), there will be a step of “connect to existing” apps
## This should allow the user to select to which apps they want to connect the source/connector - *in any case, the lost of apps should include only the apps the user is an admin or contributor* 
## By default none of the apps will be selected
# Replacing sandbox/placeholders automatically:
## If 
### A user marks an app in such a modal in a data source:
### And that app is connected to a sandbox or placeholder of the type of data source the specific data source
## Upon submission, the data source will automatically replace the sandbox/placeholder.
# In addition, the list of apps used by a data source [existing data source side panel] should be improved - see mocks and details below

h2. Design


# *Select Apps to Connect – Step Definition*
This step appears as part of the data source setup flow and allows users to connect the newly added data source (or connector) to one or more existing apps in their workspace.

## *Behavior*
### Shows only apps where the user has *Admin* or *Contributor* permissions.
### Apps are displayed in a searchable list with checkboxes.
### *Default:* No apps are pre-selected.
### The step may or may not be included in the flow depending on user context (see use cases below).

## *Use Cases*

### *Case 1: There are relevant gallery Apps + Existing apps the user has edit permissions on* ([see design|https://www.figma.com/design/5dJLWTbC8u6iRp3OCBUbaU/UX-UI?node-id=37331-224055&t=itDFySdRyPwuKIdg-0])

#### User can either:
##### Choose a suggested gallery app, install a gallery app and finish the flow there, *or*
##### Click *Next* to go to the “Select Apps” step.
#### In the “Select Apps” step, none of the apps are selected by default. The user can click *Back* to return to the previous step, or click *Save* (if no apps are selected, Save acts as Skip).

### *Case 2: There are relevant gallery Apps but no existing apps the user has edit permissions on* ([see design|https://www.figma.com/design/5dJLWTbC8u6iRp3OCBUbaU/UX-UI?node-id=37331-242190&t=itDFySdRyPwuKIdg-0])

I’ve updated the design description to cover all 4 points:

# *Modal when apps already exist*
Added a version showing the non-empty state - e.g. “24 | Edit” - so it’s clear how the entry point looks when apps are already assigned.
# *Step order relative to app gallery*
From what I’ve seen in user sessions in Datadog, the last step is consistently the “Integration Details” step - I haven’t encountered a case where the gallery appears as the final step.
#* If the gallery step is reintroduced in the future, “Select apps to connect” will come _before_ the gallery - In that case:
#** The primary CTA is Next.
#** A secondary Back button
#** A third Skip for now option allows bypassing app selection.
#** The gallery step becomes the last step and ends with Save.
#* In the current flow (where there’s no gallery apps and “Select apps” is the final step):
#** The primary CTA is Save.
#** If the user unselects all apps, Save acts like a silent skip - the integration is created with {{0 apps connected}}*.*
# *By default, all apps are selected when this step loads.*
The rationale is that most users will not know which apps require the data source, and leaving everything checked ensures broad coverage and reduces the risk of missing critical connections. Users who want finer control can deselect apps explicitly. There’s also little sense in leaving nothing selected - while users can technically press *Save* with no apps connected, this outcome is not practical and provides no value.
# *Sandbox / placeholder replacement*
If the sandbox has no real user value (only serving as a temporary placeholder so apps don’t break before a real connection exists), it should be automatically replaced once a real data source of the same type is connected (e.g., real AWS replacing mock AWS). Users care only about the real data source being connected — they don’t need to see or manage the sandbox at all. No confirmation or UI indication is required, as long as the replacement happens seamlessly.

h3. Currently, our agent doesn't have any knowledge of the app they work on/in.

This has several implications:

# The user can potentially generate and publish the same queries again and again (via the Insights agent)
# If we want to provide the user with continuous building abilities (canvases, and more important, alerts) - each time the user asks something, a new batch of duplicate assets will be created.
#  If the user asks about the app (Like: how come I have 88 criticals, all from the same alert?), the Insights agent is unable to answer it.

So, we will provide our AI with a tool to explore the app to obtain context.

{color:#006644}Grooming questions:{color}

# {color:#006644}what’s the best way to query the app?{color}
# {color:#006644}(We have the alerts table already readable, right?){color}
# {color:#006644}How does this work in our current agent architecture? {color}

Expected questions the agent should be able to answer:

## How many queries does this app have / what are those those queries?
## How many canvases does this app have / what are those those canvases?
## How many alert rules does this app have / what are those those alert rules?
## How many alerts does this app have / what are those those alerts / what are my most critical issues?
## How many workflows does this app have / what are those those workflows?

## Q: What queries / canvases / alert rules / workflows would you suggest i add?
Example A: i see you have covered cloud basic security posture practices, here are 5 less common but high risk cloud misconfigurations you can add alerts for monitoring 
## Q: What alerts (issues) can have the biggest impact on my organization or cloud security posture?
Example A: Based the alerts in this app, severity, number off evidences, number of  arn appearances and creation time, here are the top 10 issues that can effect you organization

## Suggest a remediation plan based on my security issues?
Example A: I see you have 3 critical, 5 high, 17 medium, and 79 low severity alerts in this app. I suggest focusing first on alerts that are critical and high severity prioritized by the number of related evidences accosted and have potentially the highest impact on your security posture 
# Advanced plus
## Suggest what queries / canvases / alert rules should i add based MITRE ATT&CK

[@Boris Plotnikov|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U075YM1ULJU] [@Leon Goldberg|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U0757UYEP60] - we discussed several time the need of the AI App Builder agent to have a broader context before generating the app - e.g. sources the organization has, clarifications (like use cases to include/exclude, who will consume the canvas/es), etc. We said that as the UX we implemented can easily support such questions, we can discuss this later.Today, [@Jack Green|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U0784CGC0MU], [@Jonathan Ydov|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U074QTY7G9M] and myself discussed how we will move the user information and intent from the website (like in the case of a user prompting in the input box in the website), via the onboarding chat (where the user info is enriched), and then to the platform and the app building initiating prompt.[@Jack Green|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U0784CGC0MU] came up with a very elegant thought, of gathering the missing user/account level information needed to build the app as part of the app builder, entirely skipping the AI Onboarding chat as a separate agent in a separate AI instance. This will also unify our conversational AI into a single instance, which is what we wanted to do anyway.So, as I see it, this is how it can work:

# Information gathered in the website and signup is stored in Hubspot (this is the current situation, regardless)
# Once the user completes the signup/activation, they are directed to a new app, that at this point is a conversation with the App Builder/CS agent.
# The agent decides what context it needs in order to build an app the user want, and the gathers it:
## By querying Hubspot for the info stored there (in the case of a first-app/onboarding)
## By querying a user/account profile (can be unstructured text, queried semantically)
## By interviewing the user for the rest of the context
# Once the information is gathered:
## The app building process starts
## The user and account profiles are updated according to the new information
## An event is sent to Segment, with any new information that was acquired

[@Boris Plotnikov|https://solasecurity.slack.com/team/U075YM1ULJU] - I see this as part of the "context awareness" aspect of the CS. The profile is just a basic user/account context.WDYT? Since anyway we see a need for context gathering when building an app, and since we anyway wanted to solve the issue of moving information from the onboarding chat to the app (and even discussed unifying the chats under a single infra), I think maybe this can kill the two birds with minimal work.

h2. Purpose

As a *workspace user* with _Build App_ permission, I want to type a natural‑language prompt and have Sola generate a new app, so that I can start exploring and securing my environment without manual setup.

----

h2. Flow Description (high‑level)

# *Prompt Submission*
• User enters prompt in multi‑line textarea.
• _Enter_ submits; _Shift+Enter_ adds newline.
• Backend creates an empty app
Front‑end navigates to Build Session.
# *Build Session – Conversational UI*
• Chat shows system message: LLM generated - _prompt by_ [~accountid:712020:8f7845a9-689c-47d4-8ec3-3c23bc7c1698] .
• Build Stream panel opens (side drawer on desktop, bottom sheet on mobile).
• Panel streams:
– *Chain‑of‑Thought* (token stream)
– *Asset Log* (app components, data‑source links, etc.).
# *Data‑Source Handling* at creation
• The AI decides what DSs it needs for the app
If the relevant DSs exist in the Workspace, connect the to the app.
• If source missing, connect the relevant placeholder DS.
# *Completion*
• On Build Complete, Build Stream auto‑collapses to a "Details" chip.
• Chat receives *Completion bundle* comprising:
a. Summary of the app that was built (prompt - [~accountid:712020:8f7845a9-689c-47d4-8ec3-3c23bc7c1698] )
b. _Key Findings_ list (if DSs exist).
c. If _missing Sources (not connected, or haven’t completed their 1st retrieval run):_
## _Text updating the user ton heir DSs status - prompt by_ [~accountid:712020:8f7845a9-689c-47d4-8ec3-3c23bc7c1698] 
## *B*utton opens the App Settings modal in the Data Sources tab
# *Data‑Sources Modal*
• Button triggers the App Setting modal in the Data Sources tab.
• Closing modal returns focus to chat; conversation continues.

column1: Restructure onboarding-interview JSON to fit Salesforce required format
column31:
[~accountid:712020:b89d5bf5-7d56-4c13-93ae-aeb60639177f] 

Since we can’t send array fields directly to salesforce, it would be helpful if we could transform the array fields to (or create additional fields as) single string with semicolons, for example:
"areas of interest": "Cloud Security; Application; Network Security",
"sources": "Bitbucket; Okta; Google Workspace"


We have 2 options to this:

* *Transform the Data Upstream:* Modify the payload in your application code so that the property is already a string (for example, by joining the array elements) before sending it to Segment.

* *Use a Custom Transformation in Segment:* With Segment’s Functions (or custom destination transformations), you can write a small piece of JavaScript that intercepts the event and joins the array into a string. This custom transform will convert your array (e.g. {{[ 'val1', 'val2' ]}}) into a string like {{"val1, val2"}} so that when the event is delivered to Salesforce it meets the required format.

To allow our BI team to get the full picture of our users' activation and activity, we need to send MongoDB the following events:

column1: Indicate when an App and query is relying on mock/sandbox data
column31:
General:

# Items (widgets, alerts, data tables) using sandbox data should be marked so they won’t be shared as real data, since:
## This could cause confusion, where viewers might think they are seeing real information
## Such confusion, beyond being a bad experience, might reflect bad on our brand
# Items connected to dataless sources (the schema-only we allow users to build apps with) should also be marked, so the user will understand why their results are empty

Basic definitions:

* A query is considered “using sandbox data” if any of the sources it is querying is a sandbox source
* A query is considered “using no data” if any of the sources it is querying is an empty source
* A widget and alert are considered “using sandbox/no data” if iit is based on a query that is based on a sandbox/no data source

Where to label sandbox/no data items:

## Sandbox label [(see design)|https://www.figma.com/design/5dJLWTbC8u6iRp3OCBUbaU/UX%2FUI?node-id=21787-58841&node-type=frame&t=s2grsUAUG45APLb8-0]

column1: Show alerts of a changed query as Deprecated
column31:
Currently, once an Alert Rule is created, the user cannot edit the query that the alert is based on. The user also doesn’t get any indication that this is the case (they just see a fail message when they try to publish the edited query). 

New behavior:

# This behavior follows the user deciding to publish the changes in the query (from [this story|https://sola-security.atlassian.net/browse/RND-1303])
# All priorly existing alerts from alert rules that are based on the edited queries will change their status to Deprecated
# On hover (on the Deprecated status), a tooltip will tell the user that this alert was created from a query that was changed.

Currently:

* When a user edits a Query that is being used by a Canves Widget, we allow them to save without notifying them about the possible consequences (that a dashboard will now present different data, without changing the description).
* When a user edits a Query being used by an Alert Rule and seeks to publish it, we don’t let them, and we just present a “Fail to publish” error message.

We will:

# Present the users of *both* cases a modal:
## Appearing after the user clicks Publish
## Offering the user to:
### Cancel - closing the modal, aborting the publishing process
### Duplicate - using the current duplication flow (user lands on new query named _copy, etc.)
### Publish anyway - publish
## Showing a link that opens a view of the uses of the query.

column1: Using existing queries in answering questions
column31:
Currently, when a user asks a data question in an app, it takes a long time to provide an answer, even if it an existing query already exists.

[hypothesis] A better flow would be to look for existing queries, use the data it retrieved, and point to the query and assets that might use them. 

When a user asks a question in an existing app:

* First look for an existing query (or queries) that answers the question
* If you find them:
** Run them and provide insights (or even use the data it retrieved when the queries ran last) 
** Refer the user the the query (provide link)
** If existing, also refer to derivative alerts and canvases

* *Goal*: Define and implement a fallback approach for any unknown errors that may occur during source checks or LLM interaction.
* *Acceptance Criteria*:
** Graceful handling of unexpected errors, with consistent user feedback.
** Logs unknown error events for further diagnostics.

column1: Respond to Queries with No Findings in Non-Empty Tables

h4. *5. Respond to Queries with No Findings in Non-Empty Tables*

*Description:* For queries that run successfully and involve non-empty tables but yield no findings:

h4. *Indicate Out-of-Sync Tables in Queries*

*Description:* When a query is generated using an out-of-sync table:

* Warn the user that the table is out of sync, which may affect query results.
* Optionally suggest steps to resolve synchronization issues.

h4. *Handle Queries Involving Disabled Tables*

*Description:* For queries involving disabled tables:

* Notify the user that the query cannot be provided because table X is disabled.

*Description:* When a query fails due to missing tables:

* Inform the user that the query failed.
* List the names of the missing tables.

column1: Notify User When Tables Are Empty
column31:
*Description:*
When a query executes successfully but results in empty findings due to one or more empty tables, the AI should:

* Inform the user that the query ran but returned no findings *(already happens)*
* And the reason.
* Specify which tables were empty.

column1: Inform user they are querying a placeholder DB
column31:
If a user is using the AI Copilot to query a placeholder DB, the Copilot should inform them that this is why they got no results.

Our queries “know” what sources they are querying. The AI Copilot should know that fact as well, and reply accordingly.

This story relates to two cases:

* A query returned no results, and the reason (or one of the reasons) is that at least one of the sources/vendors is a placeholder
* A query returned results, but since one of the vendors is a placeholder, it could tamper with the validity of the results, and the user needs to know that
